poem:
### The Soprano's Declaration

In the room of soaring notes,  
she stands, a vessel for ancient tales—  
three centuries spun in a single chord.  
Eyes locked, she shuns the expected,  
her voice an aria of unadorned truth.  
Not a feminist, she names herself,  
but oh, how her song shakes the old rafters,  
a crescendo of lived pain.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I’m good at doing pain’: soprano Ausrine Stundyte on trauma, adrenaline and playing a 300-year-old woman Ausrine Stundyte has been in the room for just over two minutes when she looks me in the eye and declares: “I am totally not a feminist.” I am slightly taken aback. Moments earlier, I had been watching the Lithuanian soprano rehearse Leoš Janáček’s opera The Makropulos Case, which the Royal Opera is staging for the first time this". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
